message.content:
cs.DS, cs.IT, cs.LG, cs.CR, cs.SI. 

The paper deals with the problem of privately releasing approximate answers to marginal queries, which is a well-studied problem in differential privacy and falls under the category of data privacy. The paper uses geometric techniques and convex relaxations to design efficient algorithms, which suggests that it could belong to the sub-categories of cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms), cs.IT (Information Theory), and cs.LG (Machine Learning). The paper also mentions the use of the Frank-Wolfe algorithm for constrained convex minimization, which is a common optimization technique in cryptography and could place the paper in the sub-category of cs.CR (Cryptography). Finally, the paper discusses the use of the Grothendieck inequality from functional analysis to design the relaxations, which could suggest that it belongs to the sub-category of cs.SI (Social and Information Networks).
